antiPatterns.name: Silver Bullet
aliases: Web Services Will Fix Our Problems
antiPatterns.description: Describes a number of web services that are used to solve a problem on top of an existing architecture. This comes from the assumption that (web-)services will fix any problem. If the underlying architecture has lacks in his structure, then the webservice will exhibit the this structure.
antiPatterns.detection: Typically have a number of web services on top of an existing architecture.
antiPatterns.consequences: There is either a significant refactoring of the logic or if just copy and pasted there is a maintenance overhead. Also the web services that are created in this way are hard to reuse, because they were built for this specific purpose and tightly coupled. Additionally, there is a development overhead for the web services.
antiPatterns.cause: The assumption, that a web service can fix the issues that the implementation in the underlying structure has. It can also be caused by the decision high-level technical managers and not by architects, without understanding them. It can also be caused by a poor architecture and design.
antiPatterns.solution: A refactoring of the underlying system is needed.
antiPatterns.example: An example is a bloated session with a similarly structured web service endpoint on top of it. This is a tight coupling because the web service is specific to this session. The expectation is that the client view on this system will be usable, scalable and allow reusing.
sources: @book{dudney2003j2ee, title={J2EE antipatterns}, author={Dudney, Bill and Asbury, Stephen and Krozak, Joseph K and Wittkopf, Kevin}, year={2003}, publisher={John Wiley \& Sons}}
